intro: Chascanum insulare, commonly known as the Andean moonflower, is a flowering plant native to the Andes mountains of South America. It is a member of the nightshade family (Solanaceae) and is characterized by its large, showy white or pale purple flowers that open at night. The plant produces small, round berries that are typically yellow or orange when mature. It thrives in high-altitude environments with cool temperatures and well-drained soil. Due to its unique flowering behavior and ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens in temperate regions.
